title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden's $1.9tn coronavirus relief package received final backing from the US House of Representatives on Wednesday, paving the way for the bill to be signed into law on Friday.

The historic bill, which includes a new round of means-tested direct payments of up to $1,400 for most American adults, passed in a narrow 220 to 211 vote.

The final greenlight from Congress marks a big victory for the US president at the end of his first 50 days in office. He has made the legislation a top priority and its passage will clear a path for the president to shift focus to other areas of legislation, including expanding infrastructure spending and reforming voting laws.

But reaching this point involved one of the most delicate missions in US politics, balancing the desires of conservative Democrats from swing states with those of progressive lawmakers desperate for the boldest possible action after four years of Donald Trump in the White House. It also involved hours of talks with Joe Manchin, the recalcitrant Democratic senator from West Virginia.

The passage of the American Rescue Plan will speed up the economic recovery from the pandemic. The White House hopes the huge new injection of US government spending will also reduce income inequality and poverty in the US and help rebalance the economy. It has already led to a surge in confidence among large US employers.

Biden is scheduled to address the nation in a televised primetime speech later on Thursday in which he is expected to address the pandemic and “what the path forward looks like”. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The US intends to buy a further 100m doses of Johnson & Johnson's coronavirus vaccine for delivery later this year. Anthony Fauci said the US should reach herd immunity by early autumn.

  • GSK and its partner Vir will seek emergency authorisation from the US Food and Drug Administration for a new experimental Covid-19 treatment. Denmark has suspended use of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine as a “precautionary principle” after one person died in the country with blood clots following inoculation.

  • EU officials admitted that the UK had not imposed an export ban on Covid-19 vaccines, but lamented that Britain has been a large recipient of doses from the bloc's suppliers.

  • Can vaccinated people still be a danger to those around them? US health authorities are giving divergent advice as research into transmission continues. (FT)

Follow our Covid-19 live blog for the latest updates.

In the news

Roblox closes first day of trading with $38bn valuation Shares in the online gaming company that allows users to build imaginary worlds and makes money from sales of a virtual currency made a strong debut on the New York Stock Exchange.

  • Shares in GameStop went on another wild ride on Wednesday, shooting higher and then crashing in a repeat of the explosive trading frenzy in January. (FT)

American Airlines launches biggest debt deal in industry's history The Texas-based airline issued $6.5bn worth of junk bonds on Wednesday as part of a package that also includes $3.5bn in loans and marks the biggest debt deal ever by an airline. (FT)

China passes HK election law despite US warning China's parliament has ignored a warning from the Biden administration by ratifying an election law that will dilute the proportion of democratically elected lawmakers in Hong Kong. (FT)

  • The White House announced another package of sanctions intended to squeeze the finances of Myanmar's military junta as it seeks to strengthen its response to last month's coup.

Brazil's Lula da Silva returns to political fray Brazil's former president returned to the political fray after the annulment of his corruption convictions, with a blistering attack on Jair Bolsonaro, the current leader, over his handling of Covid-19 and the economy. (FT)

White House struggles to address rise in migrants at US-Mexico border
The Biden administration is struggling to address an influx of unaccompanied minors attempting to cross the southern US border as figures confirmed a sharp jump in the weeks since Joe Biden took office. (FT)

McKinsey's next leader The consultancy has handed Bob Sternfels the challenge of stabilising a firm shaken by reputational crises. The San Francisco-based 51-year-old, whose current role is akin to a chief operating officer, beat Sven Smit, the co-chair of the McKinsey Global Institute. (FT)

Brussels seeks to win round critics of EU-China deal Brussels is poised to reveal the full details of its controversial market-access deal with China, as it seeks to build a case for an accord that has come under attack because of Beijing's human rights record.

  • EU regulators are struggling to gather enough evidence to bring antitrust charges against Amazon, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter. (FT)

The day ahead

ECB meeting The European Central Bank's governing council meets on Thursday when policymakers plan to deal with rising bond yields in the eurozone. Here are five things to watch for. (FT)

Economic data US jobless claims are expected to continue to trend lower in the first week of March. (FT)

Earnings round-up JD.com, one of China's largest online retailers, reports earnings today. The Beijing-based company is listed on both Wall Street and in Hong Kong. (FT)

IPOs Shares in SoftBank-backed Coupang begin trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. The South Korean ecommerce group raised $3.5bn in an initial public offering. (FT)

European regulator set to approve J&J vaccine Europe's medicines regulator is expected to approve US drugmaker Johnson & Johnson's one-shot Covid-19 vaccine. (FT)

Netanyahu visits UAE Israel's prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu will make his first official visit to the United Arab Emirates as the nations look to cement diplomatic ties. (AP)

The FT has brought together a panel of experts linked to leading institutions to talk about how to get MBA applications right. Register for our online Q&A on Thursday at 5pm GMT here.

What else we're reading

Vladimir Putin's brutal third act For Russians who oppose Putin, the jailing of opposition activist Alexei Navalny represented a bellwether moment that they had long feared: after 20 years of being propped up by economic prosperity and then by pugnacious patriotism, Russia's government had pivoted to repression as the tool of retaining power. (FT)

How hedge funds are fuelling the Spac boom Some of the world's most influential hedge funds — such as Millennium Management, Baupost Group and Magnetar Capital — have piled into special purpose acquisition companies, fuelling a boom that has proved lucrative for early investors and promoters. But detractors warn that it is not free money. (FT)

The ‘invisible' pact binding the UK royals and tabloids For most of the House of Windsor's reign, the family enjoyed regal privacy in terms of the press. That changed with the editorial revolution Rupert Murdoch brought to Fleet Street in the 1960s, which exploited public interest in the private lives of royals, and its commercial potential. (FT)

Fukushima nuclear disaster haunts Japan's climate debate The largest earthquake in Japan's recorded history and subsequent tsunami rocked the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on March 11 2011, killing more than 15,000 people and leading to one of the world's worst nuclear disasters. As Japan attempts to cut net carbon emissions to zero by 2050, it must reckon with the fact that it cannot live with nuclear power — and cannot manage without it.

  • The 10-year anniversary of the disaster has raised debates about whether Japan should keep nuclear as a critical energy source, Nikkei's Tamami Shimizuishi writes in Moral Money — sign up here. (FT)

If Big Tech has our data, why are targeted ads so terrible? For more than a year now, I have been chased around the internet by maddeningly chirpy adverts for a spellcheck start-up called Grammarly. On the 50th viewing it started to feel less like a targeted advert and more like trolling by the algorithm, writes Elaine Moore.

A successful career pivot starts with a student mindset As we emerge from the pandemic and many jobs and industries undergo a seismic shift, 2021 could be the year of the great career pivot. In every career, there comes a point when you may feel stuck, bored and unmotivated, says Elizabeth Uviebinene.

Podcast of the day

Could this year mark a turning point for climate? Britain is hosting this year's UN climate summit, COP26, in Glasgow. Pilita Clark discusses what needs to be done to make it a success with Richard Kinley, president of the Foundation for Global Governance and Sustainability think-tank. (FT)
